section-block.rac_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Steve Jenkins, illustrated by Robbin Gourley
section-block.rac_book_summary: From trees to holes dug underground to bubbles in the sea, animals have homes in unexpected places!

section-block.rac_body-text: Use Ww and Xx Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Show all the pictures: Say: W is for wagon. I spy a wagon. Who can show me what I spy? Continue. Show all the letters. Play “I Spy.”

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to pretend to be an animal of their choice. Have them move in place like their animal. Prompt them to think about what their home might be.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read A House in the Sky written by Steve Jenkins and illustrated by Robbin Gourley. Look at the cover. Whose house is in the sky?
Pablo loves informational texts about animals and where they live.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: There is a question I want you to think about as we read. Ready?
What are some places where animals can live in?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This hole in a tree is a cozy place for the squirrel to live. Show me how cozy feels.
What animals have houses made of bubbles?
Whose house is in a shell?
I see the letter w in the word whale. Who can come point to the letter w in whale? Barnacles make their houses right on whales!
A family of people lives in this house. Did we see animal families in the book? Can you name them?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some places where animals can live in?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They can live in a tree.
They can live in the water.
They can live under the ground.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud a short sentence describing an animal home.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What animals can live in a tree?
If you were an animal, where would you live?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Language and vocabulary are the foundation of learning to read and write. Children who develop strong oral language skills and vocabulary in their early years will be successful in kindergarten and first grade.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Identify and Solve Problems
section-block.rac_body-text: Start a discussion about problem-solving by saying that sometimes, we all have problems we need to solve. Then share a time when you had a problem and how you solved the problem. Encourage children to tell about a time they had a problem, but do not push if a child does not want to share.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to use our problem-solving Mind Builder as we revisit A Home in the Sky by Steve Jenkins and illustrated by Robbin Gourley.
When Clifford has a problem, he looks for ways to solve his problem. Let’s see what problems different animals have and how they solve their problems. (MB)

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: These birds would be in danger on the ground! How do the birds solve this problem? (MB)
How do these fish protect their babies?
This bird family may get cold! What do they do to solve this problem? (MB)
Uh-oh! The box turtle is in danger! What do you see the turtle doing to solve this problem? (MB)
How does the hermit crab solve the problem of getting a house? (MB)
This sea snail has a house that will protect it. What do you notice about this house?

section.rac_body-text: Tell children they have a puzzle problem to solve. Provide several pieces of the same puzzle to each small group. Invite children to work together to fit the pieces together. But the puzzle isn’t complete! Ask children how they can solve the class puzzle problem. With prompting and support, guide children to acknowledge that in order to solve the class puzzle problem, each small group must work with other small groups. Use this opportunity to reinforce the Mind Builder if children encounter small problems while the class works together.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how animal homes help solve problems.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children use problem-solving skills continually without knowing it–while experimenting, investigating, selecting materials, and working together. (ECMHC.org/Social emotional)

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about what they know about animal homes. Use the book’s illustrations to show different animal homes.
Lead children in singing “This Is the Way” and miming the action they sing about: “This is the way we fly in the sky” or “. . . float in the sea” or “. . . crawl on the ground.”

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the informational text A House in the Sky by Steve Jenkins and illustrated by Robbin Gourley.
The book A House in the Sky tells about animal homes. Pablo loves to read about animals!
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why are different homes good for different animals?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This squirrel lives in a hole in a tree. Show me what the squirrel must do to get home. What part of its body helps it climb?
The badger lives underground. What part of its body helps it dig a home?
This fish lives in the sea. Who can point to the parts of the body that help it move and breathe underwater?
This bird’s nest is above the ground. Who can identify the body part that helps it build a nest?
The octopus is in a coconut shell. How is the octopus escaping from danger?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why are different homes good for different animals?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Animals with claws can climb up trees or dig holes in the ground.
Animals with wings can fly to their nests.
Animals with gills can breathe underwater. Their fins help them swim.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to describe and write about one animal’s home.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Which animal uses its beak to build a nest?
A b_____ (bird) uses its beak to build a nest.
A bird uses its beak to build a nest.
Why is a hole in the ground a good home for a badger?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: There are seven basic science process concepts, or process skills, that young children should learn in preschool: observing, comparing, classifying, measuring, communicating, inferring, and predicting.

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Ask how you and the class might use a computer to learn more about animal homes. Ask: What might we search for? If available, together use a computer and do a search.
section-block.rac_body-text: Encourage children to mime the movement of an animal while classmates guess whether the action suggests land, sea, or sky as the animal’s home.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read “At the Pond.” It is a poem!
Pablo loves to read poems! Let’s read this poem about animals who live at the pond. As we read, let’s listen for rhyming words in this poem.
A House in the Sky and “At the Pond” tell about animal homes. Let’s see what’s the same about the two texts!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show A House in the Sky book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about our concept question:
What is it like where animals live?
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, and then use these prompts to read and discuss the child-facing poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to respond.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at all the animals who live at the pond. Can you identify any animals from A House in the Sky?
Can you find the bird in the nest? What do we say if we have more than one bird?
Where is the butterfly?
Who lives at the pond? What do we say if we have more than one frog? What do we say if we have more than one deer?
Where will you look to find the worms?
Where are the grasshoppers?
Let’s see if we can name all the animals that live at the pond! Ready?

section.rac_body-text: Read the poem again and have children act out what each animal is doing at the pond. Then have them choose an animal not mentioned in the poem, and act out its behavior as classmates guess which animal it is.
Provide a writing prompt about one animal’s home at the pond and guide children’s responses.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: The special thing about poetry is that teachers often read poems aloud, repeat them often, and share them in groups. When children listen to poems being read, they strengthen listening skills. They attend to the words and think about what those words mean together.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to choose an animal. Have them move like their chosen animal might move. Ask children to think about what they would need from their animal parents and how they would communicate their needs, such as food, safety, warmth, sleep, and water. (MB)
Introduce the new word that we’ll use today.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to act out the informational text A House in the Sky by Steve Jenkins and illustrated by Robbin Gourley.
Remember this book is an informational text. We learned a lot about where animals go when they need a cozy place to sleep, hide from danger, or take care of their little ones.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: This week we read about different animal homes. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding questions:
What animal would you be? Where would you live?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who would like to be a tree kangaroo? Let’s pretend to be a tree kangaroo and move from tree to tree!
Let’s pretend we are baby birds. What’s one thing we need from our mama or papa? (MB)
Who would like to be a part of this family? What would you use to build your home?
The bird lives in the air. It catches insects for food. Let’s pretend we’re flying, catching mosquitoes! Yum!
Let’s pretend to be a house mouse! If you were a house mouse, where would you live?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding questions:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What animal would you be? Where would you live?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would be a fish. I would live in the sea.
I would be a bird. I would live in a nest.
I would be a crab. I would live in a shell.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about an animal home they learned about this week.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Where would you live if you were a squirrel?
I would live in a tr____ (tree).
I would live in a tree.
Where do you think is the best place to have a home: on the land, in the sea, or in the sky? Why?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children that have their physical needs met are more motivated to explore and learn new things. Play-acting is one way to help them develop the language to express their needs by modeling situations and solutions.
